definition: to exaggerate/empty/in vain/old variant of 螗[tang2]

sentences.english: The rampant and absurd behavior that prince 2 for people unprepared.
sentences.chinese: 這猖獗而荒唐的行爲叫馬王二人一時措手不及。

sentences.english: They began to swell to the point of absurdity.
sentences.chinese: 他們開始擴增到近似荒唐的地步。

sentences.english: We are certainly not recognizing such a fantastic claim.
sentences.chinese: 對如此荒唐的要求，我們自然不予承認。

sentences.english: Looking back, I laugh at the harebrained folly of my scheme.
sentences.chinese: 回頭想起來，我對自己欠考慮的計劃荒唐事感到可笑。

sentences.english: It's crazy and just shows the inconsistency of refereeing.
sentences.chinese: 這太荒唐了，不過恰恰證明了裁判的前後矛盾。

sentences.english: But Japan was also busy manufacturing a second bubble of comical proportions.
sentences.chinese: 但是，日本也在忙着製造另一個極其荒唐的泡沫。

sentences.english: It was really an absurd spectacle.
sentences.chinese: 這真是一個荒唐的場面。

sentences.english: It is ridiculous to represent him as a mystic in quest of total love.
sentences.chinese: 讓他代表找尋整個愛情的神祕主義者是荒唐可笑的。

sentences.english: The whole universe was crazy and cockeyed and extremely strange.
sentences.chinese: 整個宇宙瘋狂而荒唐，極其怪異。

sentences.english: When meet the right person within the wrong time, that would be an absurdness;
sentences.chinese: 錯的的時間，遇見對的人，是一段荒唐。

sentences.english: That all sounds a bit dodgy, Steven, a fake ID for me?
sentences.chinese: 這聽上去很荒唐，史蒂文，我的假證？

sentences.english: People have been frightened off using salt by government advertisements, and it is ridiculous.
sentences.chinese: 政府公益廣告嚇得人們都不敢用鹽，真是太荒唐了。

sentences.english: Some people cling to for dear life rottenlyhit must said is someone entertainer's illegitimate child, goes toextremes absurdly.
sentences.chinese: 更有人死纏爛打非說是某某藝人的私生子，太過荒唐。

sentences.english: Who is calling me up at this unearthly hour?
sentences.chinese: 誰在這個荒唐的時刻打電話給我？

definition: to imagine the wildest thing/to indulge in fantasy
absolutely ridiculous (idiom); preposterous/the height of folly
disgraceful (of behavior that is unfilial, rebellious or otherwise in grave breach of the norms of society)
lit. not to know whether to laugh or cry (idiom)/between laughter and tears
